item.title: Customers can be created directly from tickets
item.description:
When creating or editing ticket info, a new customer can be easilly created.

To create a new customer, simply click the (+) button right next to the customer selector field. A modal window will open.

Specify the customers' name and select the services, that will be available to him.
A service-level agreement (SLA) will automatically be created for each of the selected services, saving even more time configuring.
Additionally, you are also able to create multiple locations for the customer (if there are more of them).

item.title: System notifications are now customizable
item.description:
Are our default notifications too complicated for your users or you want to adjust them for any other reason ? Now you can.

All system notifications – like password reset email and more – were made customizable.

To adjust these templates, simply go to Manage > Notifications and scroll down to System notifications.

 To preview any of them, click on their title, to adjust, click Edit.

The system notifications are very similar to the standard notification template, so the environment is familiar (if you already adjusted them).

 There are two new features available here:

  •  you can always return to our predefined templates by clicking the Reset to default button (this feature has also been added to the standard notification templates)
  • we have highlighted the mandatory placeholders, that are necessary for the template to make sence. This will prevent any disfunctional notifications from being saved.

item.title: Overview of sent notifications just got better
item.description:
When a ticket gets updated in VanillaDesk, notifications are automatically dispatched to people who may be interested in the performed activity. There was, however, no way to see who were the notifications sent to and whether they were actually sent.

By introducing the overview of sent notifications for each ticket activity, there is now the possibility to view all notifications, that were triggered by performing a ticket update. 

 The sent notification overview is available via the notifications button on each ticket update. Clicking the button will expand a list of all notifications.

The list shows all notifications grouped by roles the recipients represent

All notifications are visible – even those, that were not sent due to a rule or an error. This way you can quickly find out who should have been notified, but was not, and act accordingly.

 You are also able to view the notification body itself by clicking on the template name.

Additionally, when an email was not sent, the rule or error can be displayed for troubleshooting possibilities. 

 Go ahead and give it a try...

item.title: Starting with VanillaDesk is easier than ever
item.description:
If you are starting with VanillaDesk and you are not sure which parts of the application require your attention before using, we have prepared a initial configuration „TO-DO list“, that will put you on the right track.

 Even though you are able to use VanillaDesk right out of the box, there are some parts you would like to configure to meet your companys` individual needs.

To save you the trouble of rummaging through the configuration options, the most important parts have been placed into the TO-DO list.

Each entry of the list contains:

  • a short explanation of each setting and its importance
  • simple tutorial videos, that will guide you through setting up each list entry
  • link to lead you directly to the setting

 

Accessing the TO-DO list is easy:

  • it is the first screen you see, when you start using VanillaDesk
  • a smaller version will always be visible in the sidebar, reminding you of the settings that have not been configured yet

The list will hide automatically, once you get through all recommended settings.

item.title: VanillaDesk Help has been made more contextual
item.description:
Are you tired of browsing through countless manual pages of a software you just started using? This is not the case with VanillaDesk. Our Help is right where it should be – only inches away from the functionality you need to help with.

We understand, that no one has the time to look for explanations of functionality in manuals, that can be hundreds of pages long. Additionally, searching for this info for a long period of time, makes you forget what you were looking for in the first place.

All VanillaDesk functionality, that needs explaining or that can be confusing at first, has its own contextual help. Whenever you are not sure how a part of VanillaDesk works, look for the nearest  icon. Clicking it will open a window with all explanations.

As you can see below, the   icons can be found all over VanillaDesk.

The contextual help also offers lots of useful tips and examples on how to setup and use VanillaDesk.  

The help content is updated daily, but of course, if you find, that a functionality is not explained in a clearly understandable manner, do not hesitate and ask us directly at support@vanilladesk.com and we will be happy to assist you.

item.title: You can try VanillDesk before you register

item.title: New options for ticket relations
item.description:
Relating tickets to one another has been made easier to both internal objects and now also external systems. Additionally, not only manually created relations have been improved, but VanillaDesk can now create relations automatically based on specific criteria. 

We introduced the ability to create ticket relations using drag & drop. When viewing a ticket, to create a relation, simply by drag a ticket from the sidebar (tickets in your inbox, your recent items) and drop it into the relations.

To improve system integration, also tickets from external web-based systems can be linked, to help operators in the resolution.

The major enhancement, however, is the automatic relation creation. If you mention the ID of a ticket or another VanillaDesk object (even attachments) inside a comment, a relation to this object will automatically be created. This is particulary useful for duplicate ticket, where no complex linking is needed.
Also systems from external tickets can be automatically linked this way to decrease ticket administration and improve the resolution times a bit.

item.title: Redesigned ticket layout and functionality
item.description:
The original ticket design and functionality were a bit outdated - redesign was necessary. The new design is simpler, all important info is placed where it is needed and the ticket updating system is also much more intuitive.

These are the things we improved:

Ticket view mode - each ticket is displayed in what we call a "View mode". The view mode is easier to read, displays all information for you might need right where you can see it. It no longer allows editing the ticket.

Ticket edit mode - the oposite of the view mode is the edit mode. It is triggered every time you need to change a key part of a ticket, such as its subject or description. As these are not changed often, there is no need for them to be changable all the time. 

To fully support the new concept, we also introduced the perform action panel. This feature is available on all tickets allows you to make quick, repetitive updates to a ticket as simple as typing an email.  Adding a comment, assigning or resolving tickets can now be done in just a few clicks.

This allowed us to introduce a lot of minor changes. Better attachment handling, displaying times also in relative form (like "one minute ago"), to name just a few.
